did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Virginia Barber became a literary agent in 1971 and opened her own agency in 1974. The Virginia Barber Literary Agency was sold to the William Morris Agency in 2001. Among the authors she represented have been Rosellen Brown, Andrew Delbanco, James Dodson, Sue Monk Kidd, Peter Mayle, Alice Munro, David Nasaw, Anita Shreve, and Anne Rivers Siddons. She has served on the Board and as President of Women’s Media Group and on the Boards of Literacy Partners, Duke University Libraries, and Poets and Writers. The collection includes client files and correspondence for the VBLA's many clients during the late 1970s through the early 2000s. There are also legal and financial materials, correspondence files with other agencies and publishers, including Virago Books, and materials from Barber's work with professional organizations such as the Independent Literary Agents Association. Notable clients represented in this collection include Peter Mayle, Anita Shreve, MacDonald Harris, and Paul Ehrlich.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is restricted: Access to legal and financial files (such as contracts and royalty statements) will require written permission from the client, for the life of the client.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48-hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Virginia Barber Literary Agency Records were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2013.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Virginia Barber became a literary agent in 1971 and opened her own agency in 1974. The Virginia Barber Literary Agency was sold to the William Morris Agency in 2001. Among the authors she represented have been Rosellen Brown, Andrew Delbanco, James Dodson, Sue Monk Kidd, Peter Mayle, Alice Munro, David Nasaw, Anita Shreve, and Anne Rivers Siddons. She has served on the Board and as President of Women’s Media Group and on the Boards of Literacy Partners, Duke University Libraries, and Poets and Writers.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The collection includes client files and correspondence for the VBLA's many clients during the late 1970s through the early 2000s. There are also legal and financial materials, correspondence files with other agencies and publishers, including Virago Books, and materials from Barber's work with professional organizations such as the Independent Literary Agents Association. Notable clients represented in this collection include Peter Mayle, Anita Shreve, MacDonald Harris, and Paul Ehrlich.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: The agency's files related to Alice Munro were sent to the University of Calgary Special Collections to accompany their Alice Munro Collection.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Additional materials on client Anita Shreve can be found in the Anita Shreve Papers, also held at the Rubenstein Library.

scopecontent.p: The Client Correspondence series contains files kept by the Virginia Barber Literary Agency on each of its clients, and occasional potential clients or non-clients, while they were active with the agency between 1978 and the sale of VBLA in 2001. Some files extend to 2003 and overlap the VBLA's acquisition by the William Morris Agency.

Most files include correspondence between Barber and her staff, the client, and various publishers and editors who reviewed the client's work and considered publication. Some files include drafts or proposals shared by the client. Occasionally, files include clippings, press coverage, or publicity materials created by the publisher for particular books or publications. All offical legal and financial documents have been removed from this series to the Legal and Financial Materials series, which has some access restrictions. A small selection of files from non-clients and editors is included at the end of this series.

The Agent Correspondence Series documents the VBLA's relationship with partner literary agents and agencies, largely abroad, as they worked to recruit and sell literary contracts. Files include correspondence covering multiple clients, as well as the status of various literary works and contracts with various publishers overseas. Heavily represented is the VBLA's parnership with Lydia Galton's agency, whose files have been arranged by client name. This series also includes the VBLA's materials related to film adaptations of their clients' works.

This series contains Virginia Barber's personal files from her work with various literary organizations, including the Association of Authors' Representatives, the Independent Literary Agents Association, and the Women's Media Group.

did.unittitle: Association of Authors' Representatives, Board minutes, 1992-1993

scopecontent.p: Materials in the Administrative Files series include general agency correspondence, calendars, and materials documenting the sale of the VBLA to William Morris Agency, 2001-2003.

did.unittitle: Sale of Virginia Barber Literary Agency to William Morris Agency, 2001-2003

scopecontent.p: Miscellaneous personal files maintained by Virginia Barber.

During the early 1980s, the VBLA represented Virago Books, a UK publisher, and attempted to find partnerships and contracts for British books from Virago to be published in the United States. This series includes general correspondence, files for various Virago titles, and materials from some of Virago's partnerships with other publishers such as Viking or Dial Press.
Virago titles are arranged alphabetically by book title; partnerships with other publishers are arranged chronologically; and general correspondence is included at the end of the series.

scopecontent.p: The Legal and Financial Materials series contains files kept by the Virginia Barber Literary Agency for each of its clients as well as papers relating to other literary agents and publishers. Most files include contracts with clients, outside publishers, and film studios in draft and final states. Files also include receipts for payments, royalty statements, and tax records.

This series has been divided into Restricted and Open Files based on the status of VBLA's clients. The files of clients who are deceased as of 2013 are open and available for researchers. Most of the series, however, falls into the Restricted Files subseries, and are closed for the lifespan of the client.

accessrestrict.p: Legal and financial materials for living clients are closed for the life of the client. Researchers must obtain written permission from the client in order to access these materials.
